name: Pork Roast with Crispy Pork Crackling
description: Recipe video above. This is how to make a pork roast with tender juicy flesh, with a crazy-crispy crackling! The crackle is bubbly and puffy from edge to edge as it should be, rather than an impenetratable rock hard flat sheet of skin or worse still, littered with rubbery patches.And the gravy is to die for, thanks to the flavour loaded roasting pan juices!KEY STEPS: Use pork shoulder, dry skin, no need to score (but if it's already scored, that's ok), salt the skin evenly, slow roast low uncovered, keep the skin surface level using foil balls, and blast it for crispy skin! Read the post for extra tips, step photos, and why this recipe works!
recipeIngredient: 3 kg/ 6 lb   boneless skin on pork shoulder, NOT scored (, unrolled / netting removed (Note 1 & 6))
3 tsp cooking / kosher salt ((NOT salt flakes or table salt, Note 7))
2 tsp fennel seeds ((or other herb/spice of choice))
2 cups dry white wine, or alcoholic or non-alcoholic cider ((Note 2))

recipeInstructions.text: Dry skin: Pat the skin dry with paper towels. If time permits, leave in the fridge uncovered overnight (even 1 hr helps). If not, pat extra well.
recipeInstructions.name: Dry skin: Pat the skin dry with paper towels. If time permits, leave in the fridge uncovered overnight (even 1 hr helps). If not, pat extra well.

recipeInstructions.text: Season flesh: Sprinkle pork flesh with 1 1/2 tsp salt, all the pepper and all fennel seeds and 1 tbsp olive oil. Rub into flesh, right into all the crevices and cracks.
recipeInstructions.name: Season flesh: Sprinkle pork flesh with 1 1/2 tsp salt, all the pepper and all fennel seeds and 1 tbsp olive oil. Rub into flesh, right into all the crevices and cracks.

recipeInstructions.text: Salt skin: Flip pork, drizzle skin with 1 tsp oil, then rub all over with fingers. Sprinkle all over with remaining 1 1/2 tsp salt, taking care to get even coverage. Un-salted patches will not become bubbly crackling, it will be a hard flat sheet.
recipeInstructions.name: Salt skin: Flip pork, drizzle skin with 1 tsp oil, then rub all over with fingers. Sprinkle all over with remaining 1 1/2 tsp salt, taking care to get even coverage. Un-salted patches will not become bubbly crackling, it will be a hard flat sheet.

recipeInstructions.text: Garlic & onion bed: Place halved garlic bulbs and onion in roasting pan. Place pork skin side up on top of them.
recipeInstructions.name: Garlic & onion bed: Place halved garlic bulbs and onion in roasting pan. Place pork skin side up on top of them.

recipeInstructions.text: Wine: Carefully pour wine into the pan, being sure not to wet the skin. Transfer to oven.
recipeInstructions.name: Wine: Carefully pour wine into the pan, being sure not to wet the skin. Transfer to oven.

recipeInstructions.text: Lower oven: Immediately turn oven down to 160°C/320°F (140°C fan).
recipeInstructions.name: Lower oven: Immediately turn oven down to 160°C/320°F (140°C fan).

recipeInstructions.text: Level at 1 1/2 hours: Check pork after 1 1/2 hours to see if the pork is warped and the skin's overall surface is significantly unlevelled. If so, adjust to make the skin surface as level as possible using balls of foil and moving large dislodged pork pieces to the side (key tip for crispy crackling, Note 3). Then return to oven for the remaining 1 hour.
recipeInstructions.name: Level at 1 1/2 hours: Check pork after 1 1/2 hours to see if the pork is warped and the skin's overall surface is significantly unlevelled. If so, adjust to make the skin surface as level as possible using balls of foil and moving large dislodged pork pieces to the side (key tip for crispy crackling, Note 3). Then return to oven for the remaining 1 hour.

recipeInstructions.text: Check pan & salt on skin:  If pan is drying out, add some water. If there are bald patches on the skin without salt (eg it fell off), spray lightly with oil spray (or brush lightly with oil) then sprinkle with salt. (Remember, salt = bubbly skin!)
recipeInstructions.name: Check pan & salt on skin:  If pan is drying out, add some water. If there are bald patches on the skin without salt (eg it fell off), spray lightly with oil spray (or brush lightly with oil) then sprinkle with salt. (Remember, salt = bubbly skin!)

recipeInstructions.text: Increase heat: Turn oven up to 250°C/485°F (all oven types), or as high as it will go if your oven won't go this high.
recipeInstructions.name: Increase heat: Turn oven up to 250°C/485°F (all oven types), or as high as it will go if your oven won't go this high.

recipeInstructions.text: Make skin crisp: Return pork to oven for 30 minutes, rotating pan as needed, until skin is crisp and bubbly all over. If needed, use foil patches, secured with water soaked toothpicks, to cover parts that are done and keep crisping up remaining patches.
recipeInstructions.name: Make skin crisp: Return pork to oven for 30 minutes, rotating pan as needed, until skin is crisp and bubbly all over. If needed, use foil patches, secured with water soaked toothpicks, to cover parts that are done and keep crisping up remaining patches.

recipeInstructions.text: Rest: Transfer pork to serving platter, tent loosely with foil (don't worry, crackling stays super-crisp) and rest for 20 minutes (stays warm up to 1 hour). Then slice using a serrated knife.
recipeInstructions.name: Rest: Transfer pork to serving platter, tent loosely with foil (don't worry, crackling stays super-crisp) and rest for 20 minutes (stays warm up to 1 hour). Then slice using a serrated knife.

recipeInstructions.text: Serve with gravy. Don't pour gravy over crackling - pour it off to the side! See note for reheating.
recipeInstructions.name: Serve with gravy. Don't pour gravy over crackling - pour it off to the side! See note for reheating.

itemListElement.text: Transfer fat to saucepan: Skim off 3 tablespoons of fat from the roasting pan and put in a saucepan.
itemListElement.name: Transfer fat to saucepan: Skim off 3 tablespoons of fat from the roasting pan and put in a saucepan.

itemListElement.text: Strain pan juices: Place strainer over bowl and scrape in all the remaining pan juices (including onion and garlic). Press out juices, then discard onion & garlic. Skim off excess fat from surface and discard - no need to be exact here!
itemListElement.name: Strain pan juices: Place strainer over bowl and scrape in all the remaining pan juices (including onion and garlic). Press out juices, then discard onion & garlic. Skim off excess fat from surface and discard - no need to be exact here!

itemListElement.text: Gravy roux: Heat the saucepan with the fat over medium heat. Add flour and cook for 1 minute.
itemListElement.name: Gravy roux: Heat the saucepan with the fat over medium heat. Add flour and cook for 1 minute.

itemListElement.text: Add liquids: Pour stock in while whisking so it's lump free. Then pour in strained pan juies.
itemListElement.name: Add liquids: Pour stock in while whisking so it's lump free. Then pour in strained pan juies.

itemListElement.text: Thicken: Simmer until thickened to syrup consistency - about 3 minutes - it will thicken more as it cools a little while serving. (Note 4 for colour tip)
itemListElement.name: Thicken: Simmer until thickened to syrup consistency - about 3 minutes - it will thicken more as it cools a little while serving. (Note 4 for colour tip)

itemListElement.text: Season: Adjust salt and pepper to taste. Pour into serving jug. Serve with pork.
itemListElement.name: Season: Adjust salt and pepper to taste. Pour into serving jug. Serve with pork.

review.reviewBody:
I had a large rolled pork leg that was scored and decided to give it a crack anyway!
Fennel is not my kids favourite so I rubbed the underside with a small amount of cumin and ground coriander.  Used half white wine and half chicken stock.
This worked so well!  Absolutely delicious meat and the crackling was perfect
Absolutely fantastic, brilliant crackling, moist meat, enjoyed leftovers all week.

I had a 2.9kg pork leg from Coles ($7 kg this week!). I want to say thank you to everyone who has posted here about using this "shoulder" method for cooking legs. I've done pork shoulders this way with huge success. I used it for the leg yesterday. It was brilliant. Not tough. Perfect crackle. Outstanding gravy. Nagi, your recipes are amazing. The effort you put in to testing them is amazing and SO greatly appreciated. I will always buy shoulder or legs and always use this method to cook them.
Best roast with crackling! I am absolutely delighted 😀
A winning recipe! I've made this many time and it always comes out great, tender meat and fantastic crackling.

I bought a flat boneless loin on special from Coles and used your "confit" method (pork belly recipe) of enclosing the bottom part of the roast in an aluminium foil casing, leaving just the top exposed with plenty of liquid, onions and garlic as in this current recipe for a 2 1/2 hour slow cook then turned it up.

I see that Even Rose-Jenkins did the same.  

The best crackling I have ever made, and the meat was so tender it was like butter. 

Thanks for the original "confit" idea!!

Great recipe. Another tip
Put pork upside down on chopping board. Oil and season as normal 
Take your  2 / 3 layers of foil and cover, folding back the edges at board level 
Form and tighten corners.
Flip over into cooking tray
Now it’s all tight and neat
You can carefully pour desired liquid down sides and retighten
This was amazing! Crackling was so crispy all over and pork tastes so so good 🤤🤤

Iay have over-salted this just a bit (my fault) but aside from that it was perfect... I've never had such a juicy pork roast and such crispy crackling... Let alone making it myself! Couldn't have done it without you, Nagi!
First time cooking pork for my family and they said I nailed it. The crackle works so well. it all worked, just follow the instructions. Never cooking pork any other way.
Just made this and it’s amazing, and crispy crackle, thank you ❤️
You’re crazy if you think there is EVER left over crackle! 😂🤣
